title: How to Take a Cityscape Photograph

steps.headline: Make sure the subject (the cityscape) is interesting.
steps.description: Also, have something interesting as a point of interest in the cityscape. Place it in the middle part of the photo or in the foreground.

steps.headline: Mix it up.
steps.description: Have some foreground and some background. Be sure not to have to much of either.

steps.headline: Leave yourself room to crop.
steps.description: Since you can't have exact control of everything in the photo, you will want the ability to crop it to be exactly how you want it.

steps.headline: Use a tripod and be sure it is level.
steps.description: Most tripods have a level on them. Use it. You don't want to have to fix the horizon later. Save yourself the trouble by getting it right in the camera.

steps.headline: Be sure the sun is behind you.
steps.description: This will help light the scene to its best. Having it overhead will flatten the scene and make it very unremarkable.

steps.headline: Choose the right time of the day.
steps.description: Take them earlier or later in the day. The angle of the sun will introduce more texture and interest to your photographs.

steps.headline: Use the right exposure.
steps.description: Set your exposure reading on the brightest part of the photograph. This will keep you from overexposing your shot.

steps.headline: Consider bracketing your shots.
steps.description: Hedge your bets by bracketing your photographs. This will allow you to create an HDR photograph, if you desire, later.

steps.headline: Consider using a timer or a remote.
steps.description: Either of these will prevent your camera from being shaken when you push the button to take the picture. Even on a tripod, you will have to worry about camera shake.

steps.headline: Use a polarizing filter.
steps.description: This limits hot spots and light reflections off of windows and metal objects.

steps.headline: Invest in a good lens.
steps.description: A good lens can make a huge difference in the results. Especially in a shot like this.
